item.title: Report E-2023100865
item.description:
Report E-2023100865

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-01T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-16
  • City: MIAMI
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: LAN CARGO S.A.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 16, 2023, Aerolinahs Brasileiras S.A.’s (DBA LATAM Cargo Brasil, formerly TAM Cargo) flight 8473 departed from Miami International Airport. Approximately 30 minutes after takeoff, the flight returned to Miami International Airport due to the detection of a strong chemical smell from the Main Deck. 2. Cargo Area Inspection: Upon the flight's return to Miami International Airport, the Miami Dade Fire Department was called to investigate the situation. They requested that the Main Deck be opened to ventilate the area and check for any potential leakage of dangerous goods. 3. Identification of the Chemical: During the inspection, a pallet in position 2R was identified to contain RFL UN1089 Acetaldehyde. This pallet was promptly removed from its position for further examination. It was later determined that there was no spill of the substance either on the pallet or on the floor of the aircraft. 4. Safety Measures and Gas Dissipation: Following the removal of the pallet, the Miami Dade Fire Department allowed the aircraft to remain open for approximately 30 minutes to ensure proper ventilation and to monitor the situation. After this time, the Fire Department’s team conducted a cargo inspection and, having found no further issues, cleared the plane for operation. The pallet involved in the incident was isolated for an additional 40 minutes to allow any lingering gases to dissipate, making it safe for handling. 5. Preliminary Investigation Findings: During the preliminary investigation, it was confirmed that all procedures for handling dangerous goods were followed correctly. While there may have been a partial smell of non-toxic gas, it was determined that the packaging containing the Acetaldehyde was not damaged, and therefore, it did not pose a safety risk.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-01T18:13:50+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-25
  • City: ROMEOVILLE
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 25, 2023, at 1505 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Roadrunner personnel in Romeoville, Illinois regarding the release of approximately (1) cup of SODIUM HYDROXIDE, SOLID (UN1823, 8, II) from (1) 50-lb poly bag. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed the release was caused by a forklift puncture during offloading and contained to a 1’ x 1’ area on the dock floor. The release was cleaned with hand tools and the proper PPE. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (1) 55-gallon poly drum and staged onsite by contractors in preparation for proper disposal.

  • Description: On October 27, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon box of UN3267 was punctured by a forklift during loading and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior and concrete parking lot. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Ambipar Response (AR) to remediate the impacted site. AR deployed a neutralizer and absorbents to the impacted concrete. The crew collected the spent neutralizer, absorbents, and damaged container into one (1) 55-gallon drum. AR staged the drum onsite to be processed via R+L's normal waste stream.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal USA experienced a UN1197 Carmel FMF Liquid Concentrate Flavor release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 2’ x 2’ area of the trailer floor due to a crack at the top corner of the tote. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted area. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all spent absorbents into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100792
item.description:
Report E-2023100792

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-30T15:12:59+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-21
  • City: PASADENA
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: GROENDYKE TRANSPORT INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver stated he went into the store to obtain a veeder reading. Driver did state, the load amount was 3000 gallons per delmo but dialed it back. Driver stated at first, he didn’t stick diesel tank but stuck the gas drop. Then he mentioned stick was broke and couldn’t get an accurate amount in diesel tank and mentioned he did stick the tank. Driver states he started dropping diesel and then hooked up Unleaded and started to drop it also. Driver observed diesel not flowing and started gas while trying to figure out problem with diesel. Driver had to stop diesel flow several times to allow tank to breathe and lifted drop gun off fitting in ground allowing it to drain down. Driver completed unleaded drop and was clearing hose when he seen product coming from drop. Driver cleaned up with spill pads. Driver reported to store but left scene with cones around spill to later return and put down oil dry to finish cleanup.

  • City: OKLAHOMA CITY

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LOO experienced a UN1789 Blue Whale Muriatic Acid release from multiple boxes each containing (4) 1-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-cups of product released to a 4’ x 4’ area of the trailer floor due to a load shift. Sodium bicarb and absorbents were deployed to clean and neutralize the impacted area. All impacted absorbents, impacted cardboard, and cleanup debris were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. All damaged bottles of product were placed into a separate 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On October 16, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1993 was crushed in transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. Crews collected the damaged five (5) gallon drum and placed it in a drum for disposal. FCE personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and worked them in with hand tools. Crews utilized absorbent pads to remove any residual product from the impacted area. All UN1993 impacted material was collected and containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal by R+L.

item.title: Report E-2023100758
item.description:
Report E-2023100758

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-30T15:12:59+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-16
  • City: KENNESAW
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 16, 2023, one (1) one-gallon jug of UN1903 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately ten (10) ounces of product to the loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel utilized hand tools and absorbents powder to remediate the UN1903-impacted trailer floor. All impacted material was collected and containerized into two (2) 55-gallon drums for transport and disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023100408
item.description:
Report E-2023100408

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-04T06:23:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-30
  • City: Selma
  • State: VA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX Transportation
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/30/23, at 2104, personnel in the CSXT Clifton Forge yard reported NATX400224, a loaded tank car of Anhydrous Ammonia, was suspected to leaking. The car was isolated and the shipper, Advansix, was notified via CHEMTREC (Report 2023-10-01-00001). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, as well as a CSXT Manager of Hazardous Materials, were dispatched to the scene and found product leaking through the pressure relief valve. CSX and contractor personnel contained the release with application of an emergency capping kit until such time that the contents of the leaking car were transloaded into tank car NATX400291. Additionally, response personnel utilized a highway transport truck to unload approximately 4,000 liquid gallons of product that could not be safely loaded into the NATX 400291 due to volumetric outage constraints. Because the leaking car was not equipped with a gauging device, response personnel were unable to determine the specific reason why the identified calf car could not accept the entire load; however, it is suspected that the NATX 400224 was originally overloaded prior to the pressure relief device failure. Upon completion of the product transload, response personnel purged the leaking car to clean/empty status. All issues identified and corrective actions were communicated to the shipper’s representative (Christian Beale 804-731-8124). While the car was suspected to be overloaded, the pressure relief device continued to leak for the duration of the unloading process- even at acceptable load volume and pressure. Because of the this, the pressure relief device was identified as non-conforming and an AAR form QA 7.1 was filed.

item.title: Report X-2023090198
item.description:
Report X-2023090198

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-04T06:23:51+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-09
  • City: MEMPHIS
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/9/2023 at approximately 1430, Dangerous Good Administration received a call from Employee 658069 at the hub facility in Memphis, reporting a spill incident, involving an undeclared corrosive liquid. The shipment consists of 1 fiberboard box conaining six 64oz bottles of Clobber drain cleaner. Per an online safety data safety, the shipment contained concentrated sulfuric acid and is classifed as UN 1830. Three of the bottles spilled from the package resulting in sizable spill and contaminating an estimated 30 packages. A vendor was called in the contain the spill. The affected shipments have been handles accrodingly. Further investigation revealed the spilled package was not declared as dangerous goods, in compliance with IATA Regulations. The shipment is places in a salvage drum and is being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Hazmat was found at unload door 24 on 9/25/23 during the preload sort at about 3 AM, package was leaking contents from the bottom of the package onto the floor. Quality Assurance was notified and immediately cleaned up the spill. DescribePack: External inspection showed that liquid was protruding from the fiberboard box onto the floor and continued to leak after being placed in a hazardous tote. Internal inspection showed that the plastic bag of isopropyl alcohol (UN1219) was contained in a cardboard box and the box was leaking from the bottom of the package, not the lid/closure. Therefore, the plastic bag was punctured and leaking out product. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Proper PPE equipment was used to contain the spill by notifying Quality Assurance immediately. Absorbency Pads, a hazardous tote, and gloves were properly used.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found leaking and also emitting a visible gas on door 65 in load 6 of the RORS Unload. Package was taken by QA personnel out of the load area and was isolated from the rest of the staff. Package had a powerful odor, vapor and liquid leaking out of it. Package had Fully Regulated HazMat labeling Corrosive) and was determined to be a HazMat. The package was put in a plastic bin to prevent it from melting through the metal/cardboard. The item was also put next to a vent in the HazMat Cage to prevent inhalation. DescribePack: 1 of the 4 plastic bottles of Hydrochloric Acid had a loose cap, which allowed for the acid to leak out, this caused a chemical reaction that destroyed the box, and also rusted the metal plate on door 65 that it was placed on. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Package was taken to the HazMat Cage for isolation and processing.

The crew located 8 jugs of the Spartan Oven & Grill Cleaner in 4 boxes that were damaged. The release impacted a 10’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor. The impacted area was cleaned and neutralized with citric acid and absorbents. Contractors generated a 55-gallon poly drum of waste filled with damaged jugs, the impacted pallet, and neutralized absorbents. The waste was left at the terminal to be managed by terminal personnel.

  • Description: Tank truck and pup trailer were involved in a rollover incident while trying to enter the customer's site- Costco Wholesale, 300 W. Dimond Blvd, Anchorage, AK. The tank shell failed when it experienced an abrasion during the rollover. The driver was removed from the vehicle and the fire dept placed putty on the tank shell to stop the release of additional hazardous material. Once the scene was rendered safe by the fire department, cleanup operations commenced with the placement of absorbent boom and absorbent materials. Storm drains and manways were blocked. Released matter was contained to less than a 200 square foot area. Product was transferred out of the containers and delivered to the intended destination. Variance of what was lifted versus metered into the customer tank was approximately 20USWG.

  • Carrier/Reporter: CSX CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/23/2023 at 0139 hours a 16 rail car and 1 locomotive derailed in Hyattsville, Maryland at BAA 33.4 milepost at the Baltimore Avenue crossing intersecting Emerson Street. UTLX910325 (residue UN2370 Hexene) and UTLX91084 (residue UN1075 liquefied petroleum gas) derailed on their side with no leaks. 14 closed hopper cars with polyurethane pellets derailed with various orientations and varying levels of leaked pellets. The shipper, Shell Chemical, was notified via CHEMTREC (report 2023-0923-00020). HEPACO, a CSXT emergency response contractor, as well as (2) Managers of Hazardous Materials from CSX, were dispatched to the scene to assess the damaged hazardous material tank cars, contain leaked pellets, and remediate a minor fuel release from the derailed locomotive. The crossing at Baltimore Avenue and Emerson Street were closed for approximately 7 days as a result of the derailment.

  • Description: During the morning sort at our ramp location in Romulus MI, a plastic Jerrican was punctured containing UN 3264, Corrosive liquid, acidic, inorganic, n.o.s (Aluminum Hydroxychloride) at the bottom of the piece. No other packages were compromised because of this leak. The jerrican was contained in a salvage drum to prevent further leakage. Consignee was contacted to inform customer of the damaged package and inquire for disposition.

item.title: Report X-2023081733
item.description:
Report X-2023081733

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-03T00:35:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-06
  • City: OAKLAND
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 8/6/2023 at approximately 0020, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 916791 at the hub facility in Oakland, reporting an undeclared paint spill. The shipment consisted of one fiberboard box containing one 2-liter metal can of paint. The shipment was disovered leaking during sort. It appears the closure failed on the inner container, resulting in spillage. Further investigation revealing that rthe contents that spilled appears to be paint, as the inner container is marked as "Coffee Bean Stain". The package is not marked, labeled, or prepared as dangerous goods shipment. The shipment has been placed in a salvage drum and being held, pending an investigation by the FAA.

item.title: Report X-2023081356
item.description:
Report X-2023081356

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-03T00:35:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-14
  • City: MCCOMB
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 14, CN Transportation crews observed liquid dripping down the sides on UTLX 125075. The railcar was isolated and all required notifications were made. CN response contractor responded to the site. Upon approaching the railcar, liquid was observed streaming down the sides of the railcar and pooling on the ground below the railcar. Under closer inspection, liquid was observed coming from the liquid eduction line. Attempts were made to tighten the cap and were unsuccessful. The pressure was relieved which stopped the leak. The liquid eduction cap was again attempted to be tightened again; 7 additional turns were achieved. The cap was removed to check if a gasket was installed. No gasket was observed. A gasket was installed in the liquid eduction cap and teflon tape was applied to the threads. The liquid eduction cap was properly installed. The exterior of the railcar was decontaminated. The railcar was released onto destination.

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-30T15:12:59+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-31
  • City: DARROW
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: MARTIN TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver arrived at the customer in Bumside, LA. When he stopped at the guard shack to check in, he noticed product coming from his crash box on top of the trailer. Driver climbed on top of the trailer to see where the product was coming from. Upon inspection, driver could see that the grommet where the air/nitrogen line hooks up had a crack in it. At this time it appeared this was what had caused the leak. Mechanic was called out to make repairs by replacing the grommet. Once mechanic got on scene, he discovered that the valve had been left open causing the product to come out of the line. Mechanic replaced the cracked grommet and closed the valve. Environmental company was called out to clean the product off the ground and to clean the trailer. Driver was able to off load without any further issues.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-11-03T00:35:02+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-31
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: BNSF RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: ODOT Hazmat Inspector C. Kuenzi identified the SHQX 50612 as leaking vapor in the protective housing during an inspection at the PTRC - Lakeyard. The car was isolated by PTRC employees and BNSF dispatched contract responders to inspect the car. The responders found the vapor valve plug to be less than tool tight, easily moved by hand and the valve to be partially open. The valve was fully closed and the leak was mitigated. The plug was removed, inspected and had teflon tape applied. The car was fully secured and inspected, then released back into transportation. All released LPG dissipated and no clean up was necessary. Estimated release volumes are only based upon a best estimate as observed by responders.
